chapterTitle: Some Lessons From Capital Market History

columns.text: In this problem, we will look at the behavior of the market and how the historical data can be used to predict the future trends and behavior of the stocks.

**a.** A 20/20 hindsight generally means looking back at something with a clearer understanding of what went through during that time. In terms of this question, it essentially asks which was the best investment between the years 1926 and 1935 based on all the given data in the table.

In order to identify this, we can look at the average rate of return for all the investments during this timeframe. To take the average, we simply add all the values under the investment and divide it by the number of years which is $10$ years.

Solving for the annual rate of return by dividing the value above by the number of years, we will get:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual Rate of Return}&=\dfrac{105.68}{10}\\[ 15 pt]
&=10.568\%
\end{aligned}$$

This means that Large Company Stocks had an average of $10.568\%$ return from 1926 to 1935

For Long-term Government Bonds:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sum of Annual Return}&=5.69+6.58+1.15+4.39+4.47\\
&+(-2.15)+8.51+1.92+7.59+4.20\\[15 pt]
&=42.35\\

\end{aligned}$$

Solving for the annual rate of return by dividing the value above by the number of years, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual Rate of Return}&=\dfrac{42.35}{10}\\[15 pt]
&=4.235\%
\end{aligned}$$

This means that Long-Term Government Bonds had an average of $4.235\%$ return from 1926 to 1935

For US Treasury Bills:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sum of Annual Return}&=3.30+3.15+4.05+4.47+2.27\\
&+1.15+0.88+0.52+0.27+0.17\\
&=20.23\\

\end{aligned}$$

Solving for the annual rate of return by dividing the value above by the number of years, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual Rate of Return}&=\dfrac{20.23}{10}\\
&=2.023\%
\end{aligned}$$

This means that US Treasury Bills had an average of $2.023\%$ return from 1926 to 1935

Solving for the annual rate of return by dividing the value above by the number of years, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual Rate of Return}&=\dfrac{-26.68}{10}\\
&=-2.668\%
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the Consumer Price Index had an average of $-2.668\%$ return from 1926 to 1935
As we can see, in hindsight, the best investment was the Large Company Stocks as they have an average annual rate of return of $10.568\%$

**b.** The phrase low risk, low reward is often the reason why not a lot of people invest in small stocks. The price of the stock may be low but they may not be as profitable as the larger stocks. 

Additionally, smaller stocks often represent companies that are just starting out or are recovering from huge financial losses. People often stray away from these companies as they tend to stick to the more established companies for fear that their small investment might become a huge loss in the future.

**c.** For this problem, we need to look at the table to pinpoint the exact occurrence of the lowest return for each investment. 

The smallest rate of return for Large Company Stocks is $-43.60\%$ which occurred in $1931$

For the Long-Term Government Bonds, the lowest is $-25.61\%$ which occurred in $2009$

For the US Treasury bills, the lowest is $0.03\%$ in $2014$

For the Consumer Price Index the lowest was on $1932$ where it gave a return of $-10.27\%$
**d.** Large company stocks gave a return of more than $30\%$ $19$ times while they gave a less than $-20\%$ return only $5$ times from $1926-2016$

**e.** For the large company stocks, the longest winning streak is $9$ years from $1991-1999$. On the other hand, the longest winning streak for the long-term government bonds occurred between the years $1932-1946$ for a total of $15$ years

**f.** The T-bill portfolio or the US Treasury Bills portfolio never gave out a negative return since they are essentially considered risk-free since the government is backing up these investments. In exchange for this risk-free investment, T-bills only offer very low rates of return.
